2. Known conceptions about nuclear

radiation and radiation in general After the catastrophic events in Chernobyl in 1986 nuclear radiation (alpha-, beta- and gamma-radi-ation) was a trending topic. In succession of this incident there were different studies (Eijkelhof et al 1990, Lijnse et al 1990, Boyes and Stanisstreet 1994, Millar 1994, Millar and Gill 1996) that dealt with the term nuclear radiation in the early nine-ties. Most of these studies worked with interviews and questionnaires. Different results obtained from the studies implied that students are not aware of the difference between contamination and irradia-tion. The students in those studies also struggled with the concept of activation concerning radioac-tive particles. In addition there is a study (Boyes and Stanisstreet 1997) proclaiming a link between radioactivity and global warming effects like the greenhouse effect. In their study, Henriksen and Jorde (2001) investigated 195 students and their written responses to teaching units. According to their findings they documented several conceptions that match previous studies (Durant et al 1989, Lijnse et al 1990, Klaassen 1995). Students have concerns, that ionizing radiation is unnatural and dangerous. They also discern between good radiation (radia-tion in nature and/or medicine) and bad radiation (e.g. radiation from nuclear weapons). The most interesting result is the lack of distinction between the concept of radiation and radioactive material. Students confuse those different ideas with the con-ception of irradiation of material leading to quotes like ‘Irradiated food might contain “ radiation remnants” ’ (Henriksen and Jorde 2001). Mixing up those ideas leads to clear misconceptions about radiation. Although it is correct, that contamination with radioactive material turns a material into a source of radiation, this principle cannot be trans-ferred to irradiation with electromagnetic radiation. Prather (2005) focused his research on the conceptions about radioactive decay and the principle of half-life. In his study he first interviewed ten students to investigate their knowledge about radioactivity. Afterwards 277 students from the introductory physics course were confronted with different problems concerning contamination and irradiation. Their written responses to open questions were analysed. Prather highlights the problem of not distinguishing between contamination and irradiation. In addition he implies that students’ do not have a good conception of the role of atoms in radioactive decay. There are conceptions of disappearing atoms and valence electrons that are flying from the atom. There is also the conception that when an object is exposed to radiation it becomes radioactive (see also Prather and Harrington 2001, Henriksen and Jorde 2001). The last conception is true for a high-energy gamma radiation, that may excite the nuclei, but false for the rest of the spectrum.

Mubeen et al (2008) investigated the knowl- edge of 112 medical students about ionizing and non-ionizing radiation. The problem of the confusing concept of irradiated objects is con-firmed in this study. Only 40% of the students could answer the question of whether the x-ray room is emitting radiation after being exposed to x-rays or not in the right way. The majority (80%) of the investigated students also had a problem with identifying that magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) involves non-ionizing radiation. All studies above dealt with nuclear radiation to a great degree. None of those studies investi-gated especially gamma radiation. A gap in the literature is visible on this specific topic. Being aware of these results, the focus is brought to electromagnetic radiation in general. In 2011, Neumann and Hopf were the first to investigate conceptions in a more general way. They conducted their study by analysing chil-dren’s drawings and interviewed a subgroup of their sample. More than 500 children between 10 and 12 years old were investigated. Neumann and Hopf (2011, 2012, 2013) found out that most of the children associate the sun with the term radia-tion. They assume in their discussion, that ‘these results are strongly influenced by the German lan-guage since the German word Strahlung (=radia-tion) is commonly used in everyday speech, especially in connection with the word “Sun”’ (Neumann and Hopf 2013). Light bulbs and mobile phones were also depicted frequently by the students. In addition to those drawings a motif shift from the sun (younger) to artificial sources Students’ conceptions of radiation and what to do about them Physics Education January 2017(older) was visible. Neumann and Hopf discussed the problem of drawing something invisible and the limits of getting concepts from drawings. The problem with this method is the difficulty to draw something invisible and the consequent result of gaining associations instead of conceptions. In their following study, Neumann and Hopf (2012) conducted semi-structured interviews with fifty students (aged between 14 and 16 years). The results produced six general conceptions of radiation (table 1) and a conception of potential risks for different types of radiation. It is an inter - esting result that about 60% of the students’ sees mobile phone radiation as harmful. This leads to the hypotheses that most of those students do not have a good concept of the potential risk of non ionizing radiation or they do not know that mobile phone radiation is non ionizing at all. Rego and Peralta (2006) conducted a study about the knowledge of large sample of Portuguese students (n = 1246) at different school levels (age 12– 18) and at the university. They used a multiple-choice questionnaire asking about gen-eral radiation physics, radiology and radiologi-cal safety. They found that students were unable to distinguish between non-ionizing and ionizing radiation. The difference between various types of radiation was largely unknown. The most sur - prising result was that most younger students (pre-university) didn’ t identify visible radiation as a kind of radiation. They close their article with the following sentence: ‘ Radiation issues must be one of the topics present in non-university phys-ics programs or else an important aspect of our modern daily life will continue to be a mystery’ (Rego and Peralta 2006). Since their study, little has changed in physics education.

Plotz and Hopf (2016a, 2016b) found that students are confused by the nature of radiation in general. The students’ struggled with the question of whether radiation is artificial or natural. The concepts of natural and artificial are important for different fields in science education. In biol-ogy the term natural is often related to the idea of ‘not dangerous’. This is especially demon- strated in discussions about genetically modified food (Oschatz 2011). In addition they found some interesting concepts concerning the danger of radiation. Students argue with a threshold model to explain the danger of radiation. The actual dan-ger of radiation to the human body depended only on the dose and not on the ionizing energy of the radiation. The students did not show any under - standing of the stochastic process behind the rela-tion of radiation and the effect on humans. Summing up this section there are some con- ceptions documented in the literature. The strong-est conception is the misunderstanding between the concept of contamination and irradiation. This conception seems to be the common ground of those studies. The documented conceptions of electromagnetic radiation appear only to have discovered the tip of the iceberg.
3. Known conceptions of different kinds
of radiation
3.1 . Infrared radiation

Libarkin et al (2011) focused on infrared (IR) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation in their research. They conducted semi-structured interviews and devel-oped a questionnaire with questions about IR, UV and visible light. The students in this study (n = 283) were aged between 10 and 16. Asking questions concerning IR-radiation Libarkin et al found a lack of knowledge; scarcely any of the students had heard of this kind of radiation. Students were curious about different character - istics of infrared radiation, like if it is dangerous or why it is red. These findings were extended by Neumann and Hopf (2012). They found that stu-dents know about infrared radiation because they remember the word infrared from the IR-ports on their phones. However, the students were not able to explain infrared radiation or the characteristics of this kind of radiation.

Additionally, UV is described as ‘light’, ‘bright light’, ‘strong rays’, ‘very violet’, ‘a colour like red, blue, purple light’ or ‘harmful rays’. A problematic misconception is revealed in their analyses. About 80% of the students ‘believe that it is possible to see objects in the presence of ultraviolet light alone’ (Libarkin et al 2011). The students saw ultraviolet light as a kind of light and therefore visible. Libarkin et al (2011) also docu-mented that some students gave UV a colour, a concept also found by Lieb et al (2016) in their study. An interesting side note was that some stu-dents knew about the invisibility of UV but also thought that the radiation was violet or blue. Suping (2004) found a lack of understanding in his doctoral thesis about the link between UV radiation and the effects on the human skin. Most of the students were not aware of basic methods to protect the skin like hats or cloths. Two interesting misconceptions were also revealed in his study. The first was a misconception about sunburn. Students thought that the sweating when you run around in the sun caused sunburn. The second one was the misconception that ultraviolet rays can stay within the earth’ s atmosphere and can linger around.
3.3. X-rays

There are very few conceptions documented about x-rays. Millar (1994) found some connections between x-rays and the problem of contamination. As mentioned above, the students cited the con-cept of contamination when they were asked if an object emits radiation after it is exposed to some kind of radiation like x-rays. A new study inves-tigates the conception that x-rays are reflected on bones (Mü llauer 2016, Neunteufel et al 2016). The majority of the students answered the question of what happens with x-rays when they interact with the bone with the answer that the radiation will be reflected. They reason their answer with the higher density of a bone compared to flesh and skin. It is interesting, that the concept of absorption is only mentioned by 10% of the students.
3.4. Summary

The different studies on infrared radiation, ultra- violet radiation and x-ray do not show a concep-tion that is common on all three types of radiation. Maybe there is no such conception at all. At least one result fits for all types of radiation. The stud-ies showed an immense lack of knowledge about different types of radiation.
3.5. Gaps in the literature

It is surprising that there are no studies about students’ conceptions concerning microwaves or radio waves. For this part of the spectrum student conceptions seem to be totally unknown. Due to the fact that the vast majority of modern communication relays on microwaves this result is astonishing. However, the internet is a source of false information concerning microwave radiation. Sesen and Ince (2010) analysed 200 websites found by a Google-search with the key words ‘ radiation’ and ‘ radioactivity’ , The information: ‘Ionising radiation is not natural and it is always harmful. There are many sources of ionisation radiation producing. The mobile phone, radio, television, electronic devices, x-ray for medical applications are the most commonly encountered’ was found on 38% of the websites. Therefore it is a reasonable claim, that many students do have conceptions of microwave radiation, but they have not been documented yet.
4. What can we do to improve those
misconceptions?

Like with other topics in physics education, it is possible to define some basic principles. Based on those principles (key ideas) a teaching strat-egy should be constructed. However, in the recent literature such principles cannot be found. So it is obvious, that the following ideas are based on normative boundaries. The ideas were discussed by different teachers, science education research-ers and physicists and have been deemed as plau-sible by all parties. To formulate these ideas is the first step and the science education community is invited to discuss those ideas. Students should understand the following four ideas to have a sound understanding of electro magnetic radiation. It should be mentioned that there is a precondition to understand the basic ideas. Concepts like wavelength, frequency and propagation velocity have to be known by the student before they are instructed about radiation. Students’ conceptions of radiation and what to do about them Physics Education January 2017 1. Electromagnetic radiation is classified by the wavelength and ordered at the spectrum. Every electromagnetic radiation has a defined place on the spectrum. 2. Electromagnetic radiation needs no medium to propagate. Every electromagnetic radiation propagates with the speed of light through vacuum. 3. Electromagnetic radiation is omnipresent. All types of electromagnetic radiation in dif-ferent intensities surround us. 4. Electromagnetic radiation transports energy and interacts with matter in different ways depending on the wavelength and matter. The different ideas are not equal in their dif- ficulty. The concept of interaction between radia- tion and matter or the transport of energy is harder to understand than the idea of the omnipresence of electromagnetic radiation. The most impor - tant principle is the first one. The spectrum can help students to compare the different forms of EM-radiation. Because of the fact that the posi-tion on the spectrum is determined only by one variable, it should be easy for students to under - stand the proportion between the different types of radiation. Students are therefore able to learn that x-rays and for example visible light can be described by the same theory. This is a key point to understand because of the different properties of these types of radiation. When students explore different types of radiation, they see differences, so when they find out that the different types are described by the same variables (frequency or wavelength) it should be easier to implement the second principle. Based on those principles various kinds of teaching material has been developed using a Design-Based Research approach (The Design-Based Research Collective 2003, American Educational Research Association 2003, Barab and Squire 2004). The first material has been tested in different classrooms and will be assem-bled into a course for learning radiation for grade 8 or 9. Parts of the course were developed in two master theses at the University of Vienna (Haas 2016, Zloklikovits 2016).
5. Conclusion

The aim of this article is to give an overview of the known conceptions for radiation and some basic ideas to improve teaching instructions concerning radiation. Although this topic was in research focus and investigated in different time periods, there is a lot of work to be done to get a clear picture of conceptions about radiation. Most documented conceptions should be verified by other studies and there is no systematic research to reveal more conceptions. The proposed basic ideas are a first draft and should be discussed in the community. Therefore the author would appreciate comments and further ideas to improve these basic concepts. Electromagnetic radiation is a very important topic in our everyday life. Knowing little about it is problematic in many ways. The long last-ing discussion about the potential risk of mobile phone radiation and the possible link to brain can-cer (e.g. Oster 2015) is a good example. You can argue that it is equally important in everyday life to know about radiation as to know about the laws of Newton. Therefore radiation should be given more attention in physics education. It is the only way to enable students to develop a sound under - standing of the different concepts of radiation. Additionally, a good knowledge of the potential risk and the connected mechanism is crucial. The author hopes that this article provides a base knowledge and will help to start a discussion. Conclusions The responses to the Demonstration Experiment and Local Press probes suggest that only a minority of students at age 16 in the UK can provide a clearaccount of the two methods of spread of radioactiveeffects (by radiation and by movement of radioactivematerial) and that many use language whichimplies, or indicates, a confusion of the key ideas ofradioactive matter and radiation, and ofcontamination and irradiation. The results of themore direct Local Press probe, which focuses students directly upon these two terms and asks forexplanations of them in their own words areparticularly striking. Many students’ responsescontain misconceptions and include ideas at oddswith the scientific view. Only a minority of 16 yearold students were able to explain both termscorrectly; almost half the sample providedalternative accounts of both. This lends furthersupport to the conclusion, from earlier studies, thatthese ideas and the distinction between themshould be a specific and more strongly emphasizedgoal of instruction at this level. Further research on the specific issue of students’ understandings of the idea that 'radiation isabsorbed' and of the notion that objects may'contain radiation', perhaps using interviewmethods, would also be useful to clarify the range ofmodels of absorption being used. It might also beinteresting to explore how 'absorption' isunderstood by students in relation to other types ofradiation, including light. In the meantime, thepersistent evidence of widespread 'alternative'interpretations suggests that the absorption processshould be discussed more explicitly in teachingprogrammes. Sarina Cooper, Shelley Yeo1and Marjan Zadnik Physics Education Research and Development Group, Department of Applied Physics, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U1987, Perth, Western Australia, 6845 E-mail: s.yeo@curtin.edu.au Abstract We have investigated the conceptual understandings of seventy-eight16-year-old Australian high school students’ and their knowledge aboutseveral issues related to nuclear energy. As a result of their study of thephysics topic Nuclear Technology, the students learned more aboutapplications of nuclear technology, had better though still inadequateconceptual resources for explaining the effect of radiation on human tissue,but retained their fears of the potential for nuclear energy to causewidespread damage or disaster. Introduction Australia is largely unaffected by the nuclear power industry. Its citizens have never been relianton electricity derived from nuclear reactors and, ifpublic opinion is used as a guide, they do not wantto be. News reports suggest that Australians fearand distrust anything to do with radiation or thenuclear energy industry because of the potentialfor widespread damage or disaster. For example, •State governments have rejected proposals to locate a low- to medium-level nuclear wasterepository in remote regions, •irradiated foods are not widely accepted in the country; and •there is much vocal and physical opposition, with its inherent media coverage, to the entryof foreign nuclear-powered submarines intoAustralian ports.

at Learning Support Network, Curtin University of Technology.One of the aims of the Year 11 physics syllabus in Western Australia (Curriculum Councilof Western Australia) is that students shoulddevelop scientiﬁcally informed opinions onphysics-related issues that could inﬂuence theirlives. Are students who study this subject ableto make informed and rational decisions on thepharmaceutical, industrial or domestic uses ofnuclear technology or are their fears and concernsdictated by strongly held, naive prior beliefs? Thisresearch looks at how students’ understandings ofnuclear-related issues may change as a result ofinstruction. Beliefs about radiation and radioactivity Prior to formal tuition, adolescents’ beliefs andconceptions about radiation and radioactivity arelikely to have been learnt through interaction withparents, peers and mass media. Because of thegeneration and proliferation of misinformationabout radioactivity and nuclear energy in the media(Keay 2001), many of these conceptions are likely S Cooper et al to be naive, contextual and erroneous. Keay shows that claims or speculation about deathsdue to radiation or radioactive fallout followingthe explosion and ﬁre in the Chernobyl reactorbuilding have been variously reported in widelycirculated publications as 15 million, 250 000 and30 000. These ﬁgures are in stark contrast withthe actual death toll of 40, which was reported bythe United Nations Scientiﬁc Committee on theEffects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR) in June2000 (14 years after the event). Adults display many of the same inadequate understandings about safety, risk and uses ofradioactive materials and thus may have fewintellectual resources for reasoned argument.Eijkelhof et al (1990) suggest that much inadequate or faulty reasoning in lay people isdue to ‘missing ideas’—where key knowledgeelements required for understanding radioactivityor nuclear processes are not part of people’sgeneral conceptual frameworks. We see evidenceof the low regard for public knowledge onnuclear matters in the change of name for nuclearmagnetic resonance (NMR), a process involvingradio-frequency energies. Instead of publiceducation, the name was changed to magneticresonance imaging (MRI) to avoid distastefulconnotations and thus public resistance to theimaging procedure. Few children have had direct experience with radioactive materials (that they know of) andyet most believe that radioactive materials posesigniﬁcant, if unspeciﬁed, danger. Boyes andStanisstreet (1994) explored the understandingsof over one thousand 11–16 year-old Englishstudents’ about the sources, mode of travel,uses and dangers of radiation. Erroneous andinconsistent conceptions were widespread: •While 84% of the sample thought that radiation comes from nuclear power stations,only 33% believed that radiation comesnaturally from space or from rocks.
•Only 21% thought that radiation could be used for sterilization (killing bacteria) and yet 78%knew that it had lethal effects.

They report a “dissonance in the minds of children between the strongly held idea that radioactivityis harmful, and the idea that radioactivity hastherapeutic uses,” (p 139). Even students livingin areas known to have higher than averagelevels of radioactivity have no better conceptual understandings about nuclear energy than those innon-affected areas (Alsop 2001).

Students’ sources of confusion about nuclear issues or materials often arise either from theirtendency to not differentiate between differentscientiﬁc concepts (Eijkelhof et al 1990) or from their tendency to associate unlinked concepts(Boyes and Stanisstreet 1994), e.g.

•the terms radiation and radioactivity are confused, •nuclear radiation is thought of as man- made (not natural) and hence is linked withtechnological advancement, such as lasers, •x-rays and nuclear radiations are not differentiated, and •the process by which radioisotopic medicines work is largely unknown, resulting in variousalternative understandings about medical usesof nuclear radiation.
How easily are naive ideas changed?

Childrens’ ideas do change but arguably notthrough educational experiences, or at least not inan informed way. As children grow, the image ofradioactivity as a harmful agent is an increasinglydominant one (Boyes and Stanisstreet 1994).Henriksen and Jorde (2001) found that 16-year-old Norwegian students who visited an exhibitionon radiation-related environmental issues, andwho had strong alternative conceptions aboutsuch issues, in general retained their originalideas despite scientiﬁc information to the contrary.They identiﬁed “few samples of students usingscientiﬁc information from the exhibition inmaking personal judgement in matters concerningradiation and the environment” (p 190). The possibility that distaste for an aspect of science content can inhibit students’ learningwas investigated by Alsop et al (1998), who found that a minority of A-level English studentsprofessed to not liking and thus not learningnuclear physics topics. Most of the other studentsachieved a balance between acknowledging risksand beneﬁts but still needing to emotionallydistance themselves from the content. Thissuggests that superﬁcial treatment of nuclearissues will have little effect on belief structuresthat underpin knowledge of content. Australian students’ views on nuclear issues Research design This study was undertaken as part of an investigation into high school students’ physicslearning. The innovative Western Australianphysics syllabus (Curriculum Council of WesternAustralia 2002) requires students to study physicsthrough an ‘everyday’ context. For NuclearTechnology, students may study EnvironmentalRadiation, Medical Applications or NuclearPower. Teachers select one as the major contextbut may draw upon others as required. Studentlearning outcomes related to physics knowledgeand skills are, however, speciﬁed. Textbooks havebeen written to meet the philosophy and needs ofthe syllabus. See for example Rennie (1998). Nuclear Technology is normally taught over about ﬁve weeks. The learning outcomes relevantto this study are that students can:
•Describe the basic differences and similarities between the nature and properties of α,βand γradiation.
•State the units becquerel (Bq), sievert (Sv) and gray (Gy) and use them in the appropriatecontext.
•Describe how radioactive materials may be used in contextual applications.
•Describe the short- and long-term effects of radiation on humans.
•Comprehend and communicate scientiﬁc information relevant to the contextual andcentral ideas of this section.

The Year 11 syllabus has among its aims and objectives that students should develop informedopinions on physics-related issues that couldinﬂuence their lives. Our interest has beenwhether students develop or adopt new views andbeliefs about radioactivity and nuclear radiation orwhether they retain pre-existing understandings.Thus the research design was to elicit students’views or opinions on several issues both before andafter studying the module Nuclear Technology. The research question addressed was:
Does the context-based physics course change students’ understandings andbeliefs about nuclear radiation or itsuses?

Seventy-eight students in three schools responded to both a pretest and posttest of nuclear physicsconcepts. The three schools used differentteaching approaches; one was a ‘technology’ school in which the physics class made heavy useof computers and the internet, another used self-paced student worksheets and study guides andthe third used a more traditional, teacher-directedinstructional approach. Conclusion Following about 25 hours of instruction, thesestudents’ understandings or beliefs about someof the issues have changed, but students haveremained resolute on other ideas. They havemostly retained their fear of ‘nuclear’ in thecontext of ‘nuclear-powered submarine’. Manywere concerned about the ‘leakage’ of radiation—although it is not clear if they understood this tobe a leakage of radioactive material or simply therelease of radiation into the water or air. This mayreﬂect students’ inability to distinguish betweenradioactivity and radiation, or it may be that theyare just using a commonly heard phrase. Mostof the students, even after instruction, expresseda limited conceptual understanding about theprocesses by which ionizing radiation affectshuman tissue. Their knowledge about medicaluses of radiopharmaceuticals has expanded, withmany expressing tacit acceptance of this use ofradioisotopes. To what extent do these students have sufﬁcient knowledge to make informed decisionsabout nuclear issues? We suggest that, even after instruction, they have few cognitive resources formaking rational decisions about using radioactivematerial. Many accept that the medical professionhas valid reasons for using radioisotopes butfew are willing to concede that nuclear poweroffers minimal threat to a community. Eitherway, it appears unlikely that the majority ofthese students could clearly articulate an argumenteither for or against these uses of radioactivematerials based on knowledge of the physicalprocesses involved. Given that fewer than 25%of Australian students study nuclear physics at thelevel described in this study, this research suggeststhat the secondary education system is unlikely tosigniﬁcantly inﬂuence the beliefs of the generalpublic about nuclear issues in general.
